hobby.message: Urban exploration or just avoiding work?
Still chasing ghosts with analog photography?

wrong_hobby_answer: That's not me. In free time, I explore the city's underground. It's a different world down there.
neutral_answer: Long enough. Needed a quiet spot.
Got caught up in my hobby again—urban exploring when things above get rowdy.
Less peaceful down there lately with all the assemblies about.
Just here to sit it out a while.
Yeah, the assemblies dragged on upstairs. Needed a break.
I spend nights exploring old tunnels and data centers. Hobby of mine.
Most folks don't get it, but it's quiet down there.
Lately the crowds have started following, which spoils things a bit.
Makes a simple walk feel like trespassing.
Yeah. I do a bit of urban exploration—utility tunnels, locked basements, forgotten data rooms.
Best way to dodge the parade of street court verdicts.
Used to be, nobody cared if you poked around old infrastructure.
Now everyone’s treating the tunnels like jury rooms for these neighborhood trials.
Had some locals drag records in and quiz me just for passing through.
Least I picked up some broken lamp parts on the way.
Long night, yeah. Was down in the sub-basement by Krepler Avenue.
Urban exploring’s my thing—old service corridors, backup generator rooms. More home than most bars.
Supposed to be quiet escapes, but lately every district’s turned even the crawlspaces into meeting halls.
Ran into an assembly group arguing about BCI collaborators, right by an old data rack I like.
They started asking for credentials like I’m crashing their court session.
Told them I just keep the lights on when I can. Let me fix two lamps, then go.
Strange times for a simple hobby.
Heh, understatement tonight. Urban exploring’s not just a hobby—kind of like my therapy.
I like the forgotten places: utility tunnels, relay centers, anywhere the BCI can’t squeeze in.
Used to be you could wander undisturbed. Now, every corner’s crawling with people chasing ‘street justice’ since the system died.
Last time I went down, a whole jury was squatting in my favorite corridor, debating whether to exile my old colleague for BCI repairs.
Funny thing is, they wanted my opinion—must’ve forgotten I’m flagged myself. I just fixed a lamp and listened.
Whole city’s upside down. Everyone’s hunting closure, I’m just looking for peace and broken circuits to mend.
Even found the volunteer judge’s old locker, untouched since the blackout.
You learn more in the dark with a cheap torch than listening to council speeches.
hobby_answer: Urban exploration. Just walking and looking, nothing serious.
I stay out of the way. Less trouble.
Saw some crowds using tunnels for those street courts.
Not my business. I just found another route.
People get nervous now. Too many eyes down there.
Urban exploration, mostly. Just like the quiet.
Lately, everyone’s using the tunnels for assemblies and hidden talks.
Harder to find a spot where I won’t run into somebody’s dispute.
I keep clear of the groups—too many arguments lately.
Found leftover court papers by a service door, raised my eyebrows.
Feels different since those public judgments began.
Yeah, urban exploration. Always liked seeing what keeps the city running.
Usually sneak into utility corridors. Best place to think.
Now the courts and assemblies spill down there, turning my routes into jury rooms.
They drag old records everywhere, whole crowds following.
Had to help fix a light for a group auditioning exiles last week.
Sometimes end up listening to grudges more than finding hidden panels.
Since all these trials started, it’s less exploring, more negotiating space.
Urban exploration, for sure. Prefer stale air and old wiring to tense aboveground debates.
Got to know every tunnel and locked room years ago.
Used to be nobody cared who you were down there.
Now with these assemblies and street courts, every corner’s a possible courtroom.
Ran into folks holding hearings with BCI logs and flashlights last time.
Almost got roped into judging some exiled tech, just wanted to check junctions.
Mostly, I patch lights or quietly leave. Hard to stay anonymous now.
All these new local power plays reach even the deep places.
Urban exploration’s always been my therapy—nobody watching, just me and city bones.
Started years back, when I fixed the systems full-time.
Back then, only worry was avoiding Council snoops or stray current.
These days, every tunnel has some committee staging a trial or grilling a returnee.
Once, I mapped secret exits for fun; now folks are hauling legal records through.
Last week, had to mediate between ex-BCI techs and court regulars over a blown relay.
My favorite crawlspace became a jury lounge. Knees still ache from cramped diplomacy.
Funny how the real power moves into the shadows when BCI’s gone.
Not sure if I miss the certainty or the solitude more lately.
